cons: Initiatives often trickle down from high up to team managers who have to deliver in alignment with road maps. review_title: St. Jude is a magical place to work!
pros: We are, as a workforce, very mission-minded and research-driven. Seeing the patients and their families gives me hope and even when I have stressful days at work, I know that I'm here working for them. We have great access to scientific resources, awesome food, and fantastic benefits. (I had my car detailed on campus the other day instead of having to take it somewhere on my weekend. Nice!) I love that we have an on-site gym. I am so impressed with our new strategic plan, where we'll be increasing our workforce by over 2,000 people, including a ton of new faculty, which means a ton of new labs doing amazing science. And finally, we have facility dogs. My day is always better when I get to pet a dog at work.
cons: We're building a few new buildings which means some of our employees are temporarily moving off-campus until construction is complete. I dislike that I won't get to see some of my friends in other departments regularly, but I'm excited for our new clinical buildings!

pros: Best in the field of pediatric cancer research and practice

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Memphis, TN
pros:
1. Outstanding corporate mission and vision backed up by fantastic staff. Everybody seems to care and everybody likes working here.
2. Great benefit package and good work/life balance. The management wants you to be productive and in order to get there they want you to be a happy and healthy employee. Free on campus gym and "living well programs" are available. We get family sick leave, too. Seriously, I think our management actually likes their employees.
3. Modern, well equipped, easily accessible research facilities and core centers. If you need something specific to get your research done, you will probably be able to get it.
4. There is great research going on here, with a lot of collaborations between departments and outstanding seminar speakers from all over the world. 
5. Well organized career development programs and good networking opportunities. 
6. HR is friendly, competent and fast here. Yes, you read that right, the human resources department here HELPS you with your problems. They are just awesome.
7. Above average pay. Plus, a standard postdoc salary will allow you to afford a good life in Memphis. Memphis is a great place to live, especially with St.Jude benefit package.
8. Opportunities for promotions exist. People here respect talent and good work.
cons:
Not many cons, really.

It is difficult to recruit new talent here, people don't want to live in Memphis, for no good reason. 

Can be political at times, but no where near as bad as in other places.

While many organizations in academia are mired in bureaucracy and infighting, St Jude empowers scientists with the resources they need and lets them fly. The collaborative environment and mission focus have made this a very rewarding job for me. The better funding and organizational structure provide much better job security than academia.

pros:
I've worked for a few non-profits, and before joining SJ, I had gotten very used to joining an organization because of its mission, then--pulling aside the curtain Wizard-of-Oz style--being inevitably disappointed by the reality. St. Jude is the first place I've ever worked where it's even better on the inside than the image they project. Every person here--regardless of their job title or pay grade--feels like they are an invaluable part of moving our mission forward. 
We all have amazing benefits--stellar health insurance, an on-site gym with free classes (yoga, spin, etc), an employee health clinic, a Friday farmer's market all summer, an on-site car detailing team and mobile massage and dry cleaning pickup and all kinds of employee appreciation events--that prove to us every day that St. Jude values our contribution.
cons: We are growing quickly, and that inevitably means growing pains, but there are lots of opportunities to share thoughts on pain points and suggestions for improvement.

review_title: Best Place I Have Ever Work
pros:
The Mission- No matter where you work in the institution, you get to see how your work helps the children of St. Jude. 

Culture-Most of the employees are here for the same reason -finding cures and saving lives. That creates a unique culture that you can't really find anywhere else because no matter what happens, we can always come together and get behind our mission. 

I'm Valued-St. Jude has treated me as an employee like they treat their patients and families. I feel valued and they always go the extra step. My voice is heard and I have the power to make real change. 

Opportunity- There are career paths to grow and develop all throughout the institution. St. Jude also provides training and education for advancement. My manager partners with me in developing a plan to grow the way I want to grow. 

I love working for St. Jude.
cons: I really don't have any cons for working at St. Jude.

pros: Excellent benefits! Like, really excellent. Highly collaborative culture. Working with so many incredibly smart people makes me a better person. I'm always learning new and interesting things. Our unique operating model, where we focus on outpatient treatment in order to facilitate patients' "regular" lives is so admirable.
cons: Rapid growth can be painful, but it will be worth it. There is definitely some nepotism that should be addressed. Covid has created a barrier for non-clinical employees who no longer have opportunities to interact with patients in the same way. Diversity remains an issue, but there are definitely efforts to improve in that area.

review_title: Love my Job at St. Jude
pros: I love the people I work with and the team effort we all put into making this place a great place to work.  I see the changes and growth of advancing and finding cures for formally incurable diseases.  I love working around some of the sharpest minds in the world and learning from them.  St. Jude is very welcoming and encourages growth and camaraderie regardless of your title or position.  It is engaging both between all the employees and with the patients and families.  I love that the patients are the stars of St. Jude.  Special attention is given to the patients and their siblings when applicable. We have celebrities that visit the campus frequently, but even then, the patients get all the attention and are made to feel special in that moment.  I also love the fact that we are not like any other hospital. We are a specialty hospital. Even the atmosphere at St. Jude is more like a family working together and not an institution.  St. Jude is an exciting place to work, learn, grow and see real changes in the world of catastrophic diseases for children.
cons: I'm not sure this is a con, but it is not easy to get a job at St. Jude if you are not qualified. You need to be dedicated and willing to work and continue to learn as new advances come along.

Also, the clinic, pharmacy and gym on campus make life easier!

review_title: Nurses are dispensable and it shows
pros: Benefits are great, most team mates believe in our mission and have a passion for pediatric oncology. Unit managers are mostly great. Somewhat flexible scheduling in some departments. Diversity is a focus.
cons: Lots of changes have happened in the last 3 years to move away from being a unique and wonderful place to work and more toward a generic, typical hospital setting. St. Jude used to have a very nice night shift differential, but that was significantly decreased not long ago. I recently learned a nurse that started less than a year ago makes 12.5% more than me per hour (without her differential) and I’ve worked at the institution for years and have advanced the clinical advancement program offered (multiple certifications, trained countless employees, etc). Pediatric oncology isn’t always an easy field to work in and it’s quite a slap in the face to learn how much more new employees are being laid compared to long haulers. Administration (not direct managers, they’re wonderful) seems to put a lot of faith in the “there’s no place like St. Jude” reputation, which is reflected in the attitude of long term employees being disposable/replaceable with new hires.

review_title: Rampant sexism and racism! Good research though.
pros:
Research done is really good. In many fields such as Hematology, Immunology, Infectious Diseases, Structural Biology, there are many top-tier labs.
Giving two stars instead of one because of the amazing research done in fundamental biology!
cons:
I really don't know who are these St. Jude employees  leaving such good reviews in Glassdoor! It's now a common knowledge that a lot of people are quitting. St. Jude doesn't appreciate their employees! Management allows people, especially white male, to "walk all over" minorities! 
It has no system in place where employees can complain completely anonymously, if they face sexism and racism. 
Take a look at the employee directory: you'll see that all higher-up positions are crowded by white, middle-aged men! 
Petty salary. 
No scope for promotions, continuing-education, professional development! Rather managers discourage these aspects of career development.

review_title: Be bold and earn a living loving why you work!
pros: Working at St. Jude through Tek Systems was a wonderful opportunity! St. Jude is on the cutting edge in so many ways and knowing that every effort I made in digital and personalization was impacting children's lives was truly motivating. My co-workers and manager were nice and helpful. It's not a cushy-family-style workplace but I don't need that. They were good people doing the best job possible. The Tek systems crew was helpful and did nice things like give the contract employees a small gift for Christmas and we did lunch with just the contractors.
cons: Be aware that Tek Systems will try to lowball you. Know your worth. They are nice but its still business. Also, You must be outspoken or sometimes you will get steamrolled. People who are a bit more introverted can be overlooked or your contributions may be attributed to someone else. I'm a team player but if make the shots I don't like others takening credit. You didn't hear Scotty's name after Jordan dunked, right?

review_title: One of the best employers I've had
job_title: Medication Systems Coordinator in Memphis, TN
pros:
St. Jude has an inclusive and engaged set of employees that are an absolute pleasure to work with. Whether it's security guards, food service workers, clinical, or non-clinical staff, every interaction I've had with fellow employees has been positive. As a gay man in the south, I feel St. Jude has provided a safe space for me to be who I am, without the need to hide. This feeling has spread throughout the community of Memphis. 
St. Jude also has amazing benefits, from onsite health amenities like gym, pharmacy, and clinic, to insurance coverage for outside services, hands down one of the best benefit packages I've received from a company.
cons: Only a limited number of employee resource groups. Possibly a lack of vertical career opportunities in specific roles. Not a con for me - but they do enforce strict policies on employees in order to keep patients healthy, as safety is the main focus.

review_title: We stay busy, but it's a rewarding place to work!
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros:
We have incredible healthcare benefits!!! I feel like St. Jude looks out for my health and well-being. I love having an onsite pharmacy and clinic; it makes it way easier for me to keep appointments during the day. 

I respect our administrative leadership's efforts to better increase and highlight diversity and inclusion. Our workforce is very diverse, but it's nice to see that it's increasingly celebrated. In the past year we've formed the women's + allies resource group and the Black employees + allies resource group. They, along with our PRIDE group, are doing some incredible things on campus. I feel lucky to be a part of these groups and help celebrate our diversity.

We mandated the vaccine!!! I feel valued and safe and also very proud that we are taking steps to protect our patients and their families, as well as each other and each other's families. 

St. Jude churns out some powerful and world-changing research. Our resources and our faculty are top-notch; I am always so proud to be in Memphis and a part of this incredible institution. Working in HR, I love to be a part of hiring, training, and elevating employees. I believe that we are equipped and empowered to be some of the best.
cons: It's a pandemic, so we are BUSY. We're tired and stressed. We've been forced to make some changes in some of our departments to better handle the pandemic. Some of us have transitioned to remote work (guess that's not really a con for most people though). But I feel like I have been supported by this organization even on the rough days and I look forward to when I can return to complaining about something way less serious, like our Starbucks line being too long.

review_title: Truly a great place to work!
pros: I can say that they have the BEST medical/dental/vision insurance policies of any organization where I've worked, in Memphis.  The Administration at SJ really wants all employees to have work/life balance.  To assist employees with this, they have a first class gym, on campus, with free membership to all employees.  They offer group exercise programs or, you may choose to take an afternoon bike ride with other employees.  And, the best surprise of all, we will occasionally receive "additional" days off on major holidays.  Since Christmas is on a Monday this year (2017) we were also given the Friday prior as an additional holiday.  And, they just increased the amount of vacation you get!
cons: Wow, I cannot think of any cons about working at SJ.  When I first began working at SJ, it sometimes would upset me if I saw a sick child.  Now, after fully understanding the mission and seeing the ongoing efforts the doctors and researchers, I know SJ is the BEST place for the children facing these challenges.

So many of the employees embody that drive and ideal. The people here know why they're here; for the patients, what brought them here. My role is administrative; I don't have regularly interactions with patients. But, having the opportunity to serve the people that change these patients and families lives everyday is such a gift.

job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Memphis, TN
pros: The response from the community is very positive.  Everyone seems to think that it is a great place to work and that they do a great thing there.  It feels god to be a part of saving lives and everyone feels as if they are putting in a positive contribution to the overall goal of the Hospital no matter what the job title is.  There are usually free tickets to events, and the chances of being issued a ticket by local police are very slim with a St Jude decal on your car.  The health benefits are very good as well, inexpensive health care with freedom to choose providers is a big plus.  There is also the 3 weeks of vacation a year.
cons: Politics!  It is all about who you know.  If you know someone important you can pretty much get away with anything you want.  Some of the people who are considered St Jude's Poster board employees are getting away with unethical things everyday and if they are finally asked to leave it is with a great recommendation so the next place of employment has no idea the characteristics which will no doubt be repeated.  It is also a shame to see selfishness in the scientific community, instead of trying to put heads together and come up with better solutions everyone wants to make a name for themselves and keep ideas in for their own benefit.

review_title: Working at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Memphis, TN
pros:
Global leadership as one of the world's premier pediatric cancer research centers, whose mission is to find cures for children with cancer and other catastrophic diseases through research and treatment.
Cutting-edge research in understanding the molecular, genetic and chemical bases of catastrophic diseases in children; identifying cures for such diseases; and promoting their prevention.
Outstanding clinical research studies in gene therapy, bone marrow transplantation, chemotherapy, biochemistry of normal and cancerous cells, radiation treatment, blood diseases, resistance to therapy, viruses, hereditary diseases, influenza, pediatric AIDS, psychological effects of catastrophic illnesses, and the long-term outcomes of its patients. 
Top leadership, world-renowned scientists, physicians and support staff. Excellent continuing education career advancement opportunities. An environment that promotes the health, well-being and work-life balance of employees, recognizes and supports exceptional performance. 
St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is growing at the speed of scientific discovery and advancement. There are and will be many opportunities for those with a passion for excellence and an inner drive to work hard to help fulfill the mission to globally "Find cures and save lives".
cons: After almost a decade, I can say that it is still an honor and a privilege to serve in this organization, and am truly humbled and amazed every day at the work that goes on here.

review_title: Dream Job at a Life-Changing Institution
pros: Working at St. Jude was a dream job for me that I knew I wanted, but wasn't sure if it would/could work out for me.  The actual job posting/application/interview/job offer process took a little longer than I expected, but I can honestly say it was well worth the wait!  The recruiter was responsive to my questions and very informative with St. Jude information during the process.  Since I lived out of state, I had two phone interviews initially and then a campus visit interview.  After accepting the job offer and beginning employment, I've had several people ask me what it's like to work at St. Jude.  Their impression is that working at St. Jude would be depressing and very difficult.  While we do have very serious cases of childhood diseases being treated here, I can honestly say that St. Jude is a place of hope.  I feel much more hope in the corridors than I do depression.  Reality is different at St. Jude than any other employer where  I've worked.  Having the opportunity to work with amazing, brilliant people who are diligently working on cures for amazing, brilliant children who are on a difficult journey is truly a rewarding experience.  St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is a life-changing place.....for everyone.
cons:
The recruitment process took a bit longer than expected (but worth the end result).
No other cons thus far.

pros: There are always many opportunities
cons: I don’t have any cons

review_title: A "bad" day at work is very rare, even during a pandemic!
pros: St. Jude is the only employer I have ever worked with that truly cares about staff. The administration is constantly checking in to ensure that employees are receiving the benefits we deserve, and asking how they can improve work life for ALL, not just those at the top. From Blue Sky initiatives submitted by staff, to minor adjustments that have major impacts, administration continues to work with staff to ensure St. Jude is the BEST, both for patients and employees. Administration really listens, and addresses issues, even if they are difficult to tackle.
cons: Like many institutions, senior administration is currently rather homogenous. However, our CEO has recognized this for the problem it is, and has dedicated significant resources to overhauling and drastically improving diversity and inclusion efforts. The changes over the past year have been visible and measurable. I applaud administration for tackling this difficult topic, and having the character to both empower and improve access to opportunities for women, minorities, members of the LGBTQ+ community, immigrants, and all others that bring diversity to our faculty and staff. We are not quite where we should be, we absolutely need more women, LGBTQ+ and POC represented in our senior leadership, but we are certainly making serious efforts to get there. I am confident that this aspect of employment at St. Jude will only continue to improve.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Memphis, TN
pros: The mission of St Jude resonates through all we do ("No child should die in the dawn of life").  It makes me proud to be an employee.  We have wonderful shared facilities and access to some of the best equipment.  The Hartwell Center is one of the crown jewels.  They are capable of running all chips, arrays, sequencing and doing macromolecular synthesis.  The 2 imaging cores are very state of the art and run extremely well.  We have a lot of collaboration within and between departments.  The compensation is on par (or slightly below) taht of the NIH pay scale.  Benefits are great, except for a lack of maternity leave.
cons: Post-docs are not given any respect.  There is no help for transition to the next step outside of individual PIs.  Bad PIs still recruit with the help of the academic programs office.  In fact, PIs that are known to be leaving have used academic programs to recruit people, only to leave within months of the new employee's arrival

pros: This is a great place to work
cons: Growing institution-difficult to get to know people outside ones area.

pros: well organized, easy to be apart of
cons: the email list will not leave you alone

review_title: I don't plan to work anywhere else
job_title: Senior Coordinator Clinical Research Operations in Memphis, TN
pros: I started as a new graduate RN working bedside in the inpatient department.  Fabulous classroom orientation and mentoring bedside.  I've transferred to several different areas of the hospital and always feel like I have learned and grown professionally with each new setting.  I have been included in many committees, working groups, etc along the way.  I feel like all members of the team are valued for their unique contributions and are included in all levels of decision-making.  I have the resources and the empowerment to do my best work and to make important contributions to the mission of the hospital.  I appreciate the benefits and the relationships (both personal and professional) that I've developed over the years.  I don't plan to leave until I retire!
cons: Growing pains from an expanding facility such as parking problems, limited options for workspaces, crowded cafeteria (all of which are well known).  I hear that salaries for my area of work are higher with other (for-profit) employers in this same region, but that comes at a price (fewer benefits or less respect).

job_title: Senior Medical Staff Coordinator in Memphis, TN
pros: Benefits, Diversity, Compassionate, Culture, Flexible Schedule
cons: Career Growth, No other cons

pros: Great benefits.  Good cafeteria.  Some cool perks.  Nice Christmas decorations.
cons: Admin hierarchy is set up to ensure admins are underpaid.  Exempt staff receives preferential treatment.  Non-exempt staff regularly subjected to hostile work environment and threat of termination.  Management does not have your back.   Poor training.  Untrained management.  HR works for management not staff.   Lots of backstabbing and throwing coworkers under the bus.  St. Jude is just like Oz - looks amazing on the outside but is really only smoke and mirrors.  If you are not management or faculty, you run a high risk of not making it more than a year or 2.

job_title: Patient Care Provider/Department of Radiation Oncology in Memphis, TN
pros: Clinical areas have a patient-centric focus and overall collaborative focus.  St. Jude treats employees fair, and provide employees' benefits and incentives.  The campus environment is inviting and caters to both employees and patients/families. Personal honor to work for St. Jude and provide care for the patients.
cons: Cons reside at a departmental level.  Expectations of the job were unclear and often varied depending on the matter and parties involved. All members of the department, regardless of position,  were not treated as equals.  Work-life balance, in regards to clinical staff, was not a consideration.  The clinical team (direct patient care) are understaffed and not directly supported by department administration.

review_title: Started off great but last few years have been a struggle
pros: The patients and their families make every day worth it. The benefits are really good. The pay is semi-competitive.
cons: There's VERY little diversity amongst the staff which I've heard from some family makes them disheartened (like you could count on one hand how many non-Caucasian doctors or NPs/PAs there are). Administration had definitely moved towards a "you should be lucky to work here" stance with employees if there are ever any complaints from staff. The pay is significantly less than most other hospitals in the area, and the only things that makes it competitive are the benefits. There's very little room for advancement at the company if you don't know (or aren't related to) someone higher up in the company.

job_title: Advnced Signl ProcessingTechnician in Memphis, TN
pros: Great CEO, great opportunity to do give back and it provides great benefits
cons: Some departments don't allow employees to enjoy many of the incentives provided at the hospital. Some managers tend to abuse their power and treat their subordinates like children instead of professionals. For example, the management in my department does not agree with employees using the Living Well Center during lunch periods (disregarding that the institution encourages it). Exempt employees in non-patient care areas are placed under the same restrictions as non exempt employees that work in time constrained capacities.

pros: We have a shared mission and the majority of employees truly care about this - it is more than a job here.  We see sick children every day and it helps keep the focus on why we are here.  The benefits are excellent - health benefits are top notch, vacation time and sick time are generous.  Work/life balance is encouraged.  HR tries to raise the bar in immigration, benefits, recruiting and retention.  Collaboration is strong at St. Jude.  Top research and clinical care are the priority every day.
cons: Challenges include management that needs more training in leadership.  Politics can be higher here due to the strong academic nature of the work.  Disparity among the departments - some are terrific and others need help so the employee experience varies based on where one works.

pros: St. Jude offers an incredible mission.  The benefits have been great for me and I really couldn't ask for more in regards to this.
cons: I would say my overall experience with St. Jude has been negative.  I have definitely had some highs, but the lows and negative experiences vastly outweigh the positives.  I have had to work under a leadership team that lacks almost everything necessary in order to lead our team effectively.   If you work in HR, you know which team I am writing about.  You would think to have more than 20 something years of experience in a given field that you would be able to lead your team appropriately, but that is definitely not the case for my director.   It is difficult for me to be specific with this review because I fear the backlash that would come my way if I was ever discovered to have written this.

review_title: St. Jude truly is a great place to work!
job_title: Learning and Development in Memphis, TN
pros:
The culture at St. Jude is something extremely special. There are doctors, researchers and administrative professionals all on one campus, working towards one goal:  to advance cures for pediatric catastrophic diseases. There is no question why we are here. We know the mission and the purpose at St. Jude, no matter if you're treating the patients directly or serving those that do. 
The benefits go further than the incredible health/dental/eye insurance packages we offer. Special events like Judestock (an outdoor concert with food trucks galore), Fashionista (discounted department store  goodies with proceeds that directly benefit St. Jude) and St. Jude Farmer's Market (includes fresh fruits and vegetables grown from our very own garden) are just of the few on-campus perks of working at St. Jude. 
I believe our President and CEO, Dr. James Downing, has an incredible vision for the future of St. Jude. He believes in investing in his employees and listening to what they have to say.
cons: I wish there were more distinct career ladders. Ex: If you work in this job so long, you can apply for this job, etc.

review_title: Making a difference every day in the lives of others
job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in Memphis, TN
pros: Best part of working at St Jude is being part of a wonderful mission to find cures and save children and share that knowledge with the world. The hospital administration really cares about its employees and values the work we do. The culture is one of excellence and pride in our work. The benefits are exceptional. I am very proud to have worked for St Jude for nearly 18 years and it is only getting better.
cons: Sometimes it can be sad work as unfortunately we still lose some of our patients, but I am able to cope by knowing that everyone here is doing the very best we can to take care of the patients and families. The cure rates are getting better all the time and the scientists and doctors will not stop until they are 100%. The families feel better knowing that by bring their children here they have given them every chance possible to save their lives.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Memphis, TN
pros: The best reasons to work at St Jude are we are a caring hospital.  St Jude care for the patients and also for the well being of its employee.  We have different programs to help you to stay healthy.  We have a gym that is free for employees, and our benefits  package is wonder.  We have free safe place for parking.  For those that love the great outdoors, we have a walking trail on the outside, a beautiful garden to sit at, and we also have bike to ride while on our break. We have the best CEO, he cares for the families and the employees. I wish more CEO was like him.
cons: The only bad thing I can say is the salary for a nursing care assistant is not as good, and unless you become an RN, you don;t have a clinical ladder to meve up too.

review_title: I hope to work here until I retire
pros: There are too many pros to capture them all here, but St. Jude is the perfect place to work if feeling that you make a difference in the world matters to you. No matter your position, you become a part of an amazing mission and will feel the impact you make and the amazing satisfaction of a job well done. The workplace environment is nurturing and conducive to inspiring you to do your best. I still feel this way and I have been here over 15 years now.
cons: I am hard-pressed to come up with a con. Maybe that my office doesn't have a window...?

review_title: Be VERY careful and evaluate work environment before working here
pros: Salary and benefits are above average
cons: Highly hostile work environment complete with taunting/harassment. Coworkers refused to share information I needed to complete work. Only advice given by HR and postdoc office was to quit. Meanwhile they allow people whom are actively hostile to coworkers (not just me) to remain in their positions and do nothing to attempt to correct the behavior. The attitude of St Jude is that is you have a bad experience that “it’s not St Jude”. I disagree. St Jude is only as good as its worst work environment. There are many areas in St Jude that are highly hostile. St Jude is not special—it just has a carefully crafted image. If you’re in a bad area that image and how people blindly love St Jude only adds insult to injury. If you end up in one of the many hostile work environments here, it is a life and career altering experience.

review_title: Senior Scientist (11 years at St. Jude)
pros: We have a CEO that is amazing with a high degree if integrity. Dr. Downing has made a concerted effort to incorporate employee suggestions. He cares about the patients AND his employees. St. Jude benefits  are fantastic especially the health insurance that has a deductible less than $100. Work/life balance is important here.  I love our mission.
cons: There are no cons to working at St. Jude other than getting promoted can be challenging so negotiate your salary and position before accepting the job.  The quality of life in Memphis has dramatically improved the past ten years here in the City,  but there is a lot of room for improvement.

pros:
At St. Jude, I'm able to use my skills and energy to help save the lives of children around the world. Every person who works here -- from the people who clean the offices to the people who work in the labs to the people who cook the food -- know that they play a role in a much larger mission. That knowledge gives meaning and fulfillment to us all. 

At the head of our organization is Dr. James Downing, who constantly works to find new ways to connect with employees and families alike. He is a great communicator, who makes a concerted effort to interact with staff through Town Hall meetings, eating lunch with employees in the cafeteria, and attending many events where he can meet and talk with staff. 

I truly believe that St. Jude allows me to make a contribution to something that will reverberate long after I am gone.
cons: The only downside of working at St. Jude is that it is a fairly long drive each morning.

pros: I've worked at St. Jude over 10 years and it's the best place I've ever worked.  The benefits are great, the respect from senior management is visible and felt everyday--from walking the halls with us to listening to and encouraging ideas from any and all staff members. Recognition and rewards are a high priority at St. Jude--for a job well done as well as for activities in the community (volunteers, races, etc.) St. Jude has truly been a blessing to my life.
cons: The campus is growing every day! Parking is sometimes an issue and getting from one side of the 60+ acre campus to the other for meetings can be a challenge.  But I look at it as a way to get my Activity Points/Steps in, to help me stay healthy--which is also encouraged here!

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Memphis, TN
pros:
Good pay 
Good benefits - great insurance and the company offers some perks (paid tuition reimbursement, free on-site gym).
Stable company 
Lots of room for growth or lateral movement 
Raises - we all have the opportunity for a significant merit raise each year

The mission of the company is great and they do a good job at making sure all employees, patient-care or not, understand this and feel as part of the team.

The current CEO, Bill Evans, has brought many good changes to the hospital, he is a friendly, working-class type of man that is well-loved by everyone.  Unfortunately he is stepping down in 2014.
cons:
Company has grown too fast for it's HR and management to keep up with.  HR department can be a mess and needs an overhaul. 
Like most companies of it's size, departments are run differently and even divisions within departments are run differently.  Happiness can depend greatly on your specific manager. Managers tend to stay forever so it's impossible to wait one out.

pros: Great mission of the institution.  Great team feeling when working with colleagues outside of my department.  Opportunity for advancement if that is part of your career plan.  Outstanding benefits including heath care, education reimbursement, fair pay, on site training opportunities, leadership who takes making St Jude a "great place to work" , seriously.
cons: Memphis is getting better, but it is not my favorite city in which to live.  Like most academic environments there are some big egos that are sometimes hard to work with, but this is not a huge problem.

review_title: There is truly no better place to work than St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.
pros: I have been at St. Jude for 25+ years and I still love getting up in the mornings and coming to place where I feel I truly do make a difference.  I have been very fortunate to see many changes over the years and I have to say it just gets better and better.  The thing I love most about St. Jude is our mission.  There is nothing that tops giving our patients the very best care they can receive and second to that is the research that comes out of this incredible institution.  There is truly no other place I'd rather work.
cons: Actually the only downside to working here is the employee parking.  However, I will say that the management strives very hard to improve on it as much as humanly possible.

review_title: There's a reason this place is consistently voted a great place to work
job_title: Research Lab Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros:
Excellent benefits - 7% 403b contribution (as in, they GIVE you cash money) -- you can contribute whatever you want. Full health (90%), vision, and dental coverage. So many vacation days I'm now at a point where I have to take time off. Every high-tech toy a scientist could want. Oh, and free parking!

But the real reason to work at St. Jude is the work that we do here. There is one (1) cafeteria on campus, by design, so all the doctors and scientists and patient families all converge. Even if you have a terrible day in the lab/office/etc., you take one look at those beautiful babies and are reminded to get back to the fight. 

You will never have a day where you question the mission. You will always feel like you are contributing to something great.
cons: I work long hours/weekends sometimes

pros: One of the most important things I can say about St. Jude is that I feel appreciated and compensated for my work.  I am able to use my skills, my ideas are welcomed and further education is possible.  I do feel like I am making a difference and when anyone asks me where I work and I say St. Jude, the first response is, "I have always wanted to work there because I hear that it is a great place to work."
cons: I don't really have any cons.  The only thing I can say is that I just wish I could help every child.  I find myself praying more and also thanking God for my health and my children's health.  This is surely not a bad thing.

pros: You can't beat the mission.  It is great to come to work everyday knowing that you are making a difference in the lives of children.  St. Jude also does an excellent job of appreciating the employees including a good benefits package, paid time off, retirement, and lots of extra perks.
cons: The infrastructure has not kept up with the growth.  Once the improvements are made to the medical district and extra parking is added, it should make a big difference.  Due to the growth, employees are being forced to work in environments that are not conducive to their job responsibilities or just plain uncomfortable.  They could remedy some of this problem by allowing administrative employees to work remotely one or two days a week.

pros: Not much pressure, regular working hours.Great working cause. Stable job. You have to really try to get fired. If you already have kids, this is a good place to be. Flexible working hours. An ideal place for retirement. typical non profit organization benefit.
cons: No challenge. no short term disability insurance. (Zero pay if you are on maternity leave).  Bad work or good work really has not much impact on  salary increase difference yearly.  Do not put too much hope on getting pomoted within if you are the newest in the team. No matter how hard you work or how much contributions you make, you can not compete with person already there before you. So better settle down in a good position already when you are getting in.

pros: A wonderful organization with a simple and lovely mission. The hospital turns no one away due to inability to pay and no one gets charged a dime.  It feels so good to be a part of. All in all, this is a great place to work!
cons: In my personal experience, I have encountered more than a few fellow employees that are more than happy to push off as much work as they can onto you, as fast as they can almost as soon as you are hired. I have seen a fairly common attitude of "not my job". This may not be common at all levels or departments.

review_title: Truly is a Best Place to Work
pros: The mission alone is a reason to work here. However, St. Jude also has many other attributes that are attractive to employees. It offers a good benefits package and seems to value employee input. While other organizations I've worked for have asked for employees' opinions, they have disregarded them after receiving feedback. St. Jude truly listens. It also offers professional development opportunities and an employee recognition program. The hospital also emphasizes employee physician and mental health through an on-site, free fitness center, bikes to ride across campus, mobile mammograms, and free yearly health screenings. There are also health incentives.
cons: The downtown location can be congested during commuting hours. Surrounding neighborhood is uneven, but there are long-range plans to improve that. The hospital has great security, though, and secure parking. Cafeteria lines can be long at lunch. Building names can be confusing.

review_title: Been here 2 years, still considered a newbie/outsider
pros: Emotional roller coaster with regards to patients, some very tough days but rewarding too.  The patients and their families is the best part of St Jude.
cons: Emotional roller coaster with regards to patients, some very tough days but rewarding too.  Too many cooks in the kitchen and noone is working together.  Communication between departments is absent at times.  Preferential treatment for old employees and an open disregard for new employees  that may be better suited for a particular project.

job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Memphis, TN
pros: Decent benefits, top notch equipment. The facilities are kept modern and expansion is constant. The patients and their family are treated with great respect and care.The addition of a gym complex was good for the company.
cons: The personnel that have been with St. Jude for over 10 years are being systematically phased out. When an investigator leaves HR makes little to no effort to retain techs that have worked hard to climb the pay scale. I know several people that lost their job and were rehired at a 40% pay cut. St. Jude has become more like a corporation than a place to grow with.

pros:
During this challenging time, St Jude leadership has kept us updated and informed regarding ways to keep our families and ourselves safe. More importantly, we are being supported and instructed in keeping our hospital safe for the children and families who need us right now. 
We are all given good masks (and required to wear them), tested regularly, provided the cleaning supplies and the environment we need to be as safe as we can be. 

We also hear regular words of appreciation and encouragement from the CEO on down the chain, for our efforts to keep our campus safe.
cons: There are some people in every population who take public health issues more seriously than others. Unfortunately, we have a few people who do not follow the suggested health and safety guidelines, but most do.

review_title: Employees who got promoted by Stjude hospital management / or ALSAC board - needs review, investigation, prosecutions.
job_title: Information Technology Staff in Memphis, TN
pros: It's a Children's Research Hospital mismanaging donations in millions by public in USA with the blessings of bad management to fool public to give more and more millions of dollars more donations....it's pathetic to see this corruption grow everyday!
cons: Hospital is getting donations by systematic propaganda by current ALSAC, Memphis, TN. However, current hospital management is not reliable according to fellow employee(s) experience over years. Top level is made up of families (can provide names) for decades and they made good employees' contributions to the hospital miserable by violating US labor, compliance, and work place bullying with the blessings of current hospital and HR management staff who are friends for many decades at Stjude - very disgusting to experience.

review_title: Better than I hoped for, more than I had dreamed possible.
pros: The people here are fantastic and welcoming! It feels more like a family career than just a job. The researchers and facilities are top notch, and everything is collaborative. We have one common goal, a focused purpose left to us by Danny Thomas, and we will succeed!
cons: At times, it can be sobering to see the kids in here coping with their challenges. All of them are heroes, with a can do, will do spirit that cannot be dampened. I am humbled and work harder because I see these angels fighting every day.

pros: Working at St. Jude gives me a sense of purpose. I really enjoy being able to work with top minds in their field, regardless of the department. There are a ton of benefits and perks. It feels like a real community, and the culture is really great. I feel like I and other employees are heard when feedback is given.
cons:
I work with various groups, and sometimes there can be conflict and miscommunication between them. This isn’t insurmountable but it is still a challenge. 

I’ve also been asked to do many tasks outside my job description - I expected that every now and then, but it seems to happen a lot. Not really complaining about it, but it would have been nicer to know on the front end.

review_title: Mission, Leadership, Benefits...This is the best place to work!
pros: Having worked in various industries over the years, St. Jude has the best response when you think, "why do I want to go to work today?"   The St. Jude mission says it all, and when you combine that with great leadership and the best benefits package I have had, it puts St. Jude Children's Research hospital at the very top of the list of places to work.
cons: The only negative I can say is the location in downtown Memphis.  This is not really due to the area, but due to the 40 minute drive I have from my home in east Shelby county.

job_title: Senior Clinical Analyst II in Memphis, TN
pros:
1. My work is appreciated.
2. I feel like I am making a difference in the world.
3. I'm working with the best of the best.
4. I work in a department where you feel like you are part of a family.
5. I am constantly learning new things.
6. My manager and director trust my judgment and do not micro-manage.
7. The departments that I work with are all team players.
8. There are no slackers in our department. Everyone is committed to the assigned tasks.
cons:
1. Sometimes we are short on personnel and we make up for it by working longer hours.
2. Sometimes there is a conflict between projects and available resources.

pros: I've worked for 3 very large companies over the years- St Jude is head and shoulders above anything I've experienced.  The benefits they provide (non-typical) are very cool.  The pride and commitment to Finding Cures and Saving Children is paramount here.  You don't find great culture at many places.  The pay and benefits are both well above average.
cons: Parking can be an issue if you're not early.  The drive to downtown is sometimes hectic.  Because of the drive to do so much, stress and work load is sometimes overwhelming.

pros:
I love working for St. Jude! I especially love knowing that the work we do here makes such a difference in the lives of children and families worldwide. And here I have the opportunity to work with some amazing people, all of whom care deeply for our patients.
As an employer, I feel that St. Jude is progressive and works to create a positive culture that values employees and fosters their growth.
cons: It is hard to think of a "con" to working her. But if I HAVE to list one, then this is what comes to my mind. The fact that the organization has lofty goals is a good thing. But sometimes those goals are difficult to accomplish in the desired time frame with the resources available.

review_title: There is No Better Place to Work Than St. Jude
pros:
We are making kids better. No matter what your job function is at St. Jude, you are contributing to our mission of finding cures and saving children. My "worst" day at St. Jude is better than any day I have had working elsewhere. We work hard, play hard and love what we do.

The way that our hospital has come together to make it safely through the pandemic has been astonishing.
cons: So many people ask me how I work at St. Jude, and, yes, seeing suffering children can be heavy on the heart. Seeing well children from our efforts and seeing leftover confetti from a No Mo Chemo party does amazing things for your soul.

job_title: Leadership Development Consultant in Memphis, TN
pros: Working for a mission you believe in brings the most joy and satisfaction possible. “Finding cures, Saving children” is the perfect mission for me. . It gets you through challenging days because  the children and families are reason we want to succeed... the reason we have to succeed.  In my 4.5 years here, I have seen so much growth that expands the excellent work of our staff to save more children through new cures and superb clinical care. It is an honor to serve one another at St. Jude and be united in that mission. Plus they have the best benefits ever! It is a honor to be a part of this outstanding organization!
cons: I haven’t found anything yet about St Jude that is a Con.

review_title: Coming to St. Jude has been a fantastic experience
pros:
1. Exceptional resources for research and care, thanks to philanthropy through our partners, ALSAC. 
2. Mission-focused in every aspect of what we do. This is entirely different even from very top-tier clinical enterprises that focus on revenues. 
3. The mission itself, to combat catastrophic disorders of childhood. 
4. Really smart people from broad range of backgrounds. 
5. Memphis, it turns out, is a very nice place to live (summer temperatures excluded from "very nice") with very reasonable cost of living.
cons:
Teams can be somewhat resistant to change. We are working hard to make this less of a barrier. 
A degree of exceptionalism not supported by evidence compared to other top pediatric cancer centers.

review_title: St. Jude advances research and care but it has a lot of ethical and moral problems to address.
job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Memphis, TN
pros: St. Jude has developed itself into one of the premier pediatric oncological research institutions.  The name that is has developed for itself will improve your chances of getting your foot into the door of another institution in the future.  The clinical aspect of St. Jude is amazing and the children's needs are met without failure and the level of care is top-notch.  The institution is very well funded all of its needs are met by generous donations and grants.
cons:
Unfortunately, politics ruin the research atmosphere at St. Jude.  As with many institutions, the personal egos of many private investigators and doctors conflict with research projects and the development of better science and medical practices.  Human Resources serves only to protect the image of St. Jude and works at the whim of upper management.  The only people that are taken care of are management level.  The association with the Hollywood elite helps the institution but you have the feeling that sometimes that is all the institution management cares about (realistically, this is where a large part of the donations come, whether directly or indirectly).   

While the amount of money coming in to the institution is amazing and it makes the life of the researchers much easier, it is often abused.  Personal wants of directors, management, and private investigators are often fulfilled with this money.  In some instances, it is unethical how the money is spent.

If you are foreign, think twice before working at St. Jude.  It depends on which private investigator you work under as to whether or not the institution will help you obtain your green card.  There has been a lot of abuse in this area.

A lot of moral and ethical problems need to be addressed instead of burying them and hiding them from everyone.

pros:
The reason we are fundraising-the kids
Great co-workers
Excellent benefits
Safe environment
Fun atmosphere
cons:
Management heavy and the senior management listens to the wrong people
Does not promote from within
HR low balls salaries and then does not give you any way to increase the salary no matter how much training or schooling you add to your initial CV

job_title: Senior Clinical Analyst II in Memphis, TN
pros: A wonderful mission of which to be a part. Excellent work environment; I have the tools to do my job and enjoy what I am doing. I feel a part of a greater mission no matter how small my accomplishments. Wonderful on-campus benefits, gym, improvement classes, outside activities i.e. zoo day, runs for St. Jude
cons: Middle management does not know hot to manage, lack of leadership, not allowing employees to use intelligence and degrees to move forward, a great deal of micro-managing, selected favorites, employees have more experience and degrees than managers. sometime managers are put in positions for which they are not suited.

pros: The mission of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital to help the children with cancer.
cons: Upper management is very bad.  They are totally disconnected with the people who do the work.  In their opinion, they are too good to have a conversation with the non-management folks.  they have their own circle of friends, and everyone outside of their friends is "no good".  They promote their own friends and keep others down with no shame.

job_title: Senior Data Integration Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: I've been working with the hospital for nearly eight years and the effort that they put into their employees, staff, and faculty are superb.  Almost every one here is about the mission. Finding cures and saving children.  At some point we all have the ability to forward research and cures just by being able to work here.  There is a strong sense of team and a positive sense of 'we' when discussing the future of research and cancer cure rates.  I'm ecstatic to be part of something this awesome.
cons: None that I can think of.  Senior management is always moving do alleviate road blocks that might impede progress to the mission.

review_title: Best decision I made to relocate to Memphis and work at St. Jude!
pros: Some of the best employee resources I've encountered to date.  Very supportive administrative depts. (HR, Finance, Hospital).  Managers and employees  are very friendly and helpful - they want you to succeed.
cons: Parking options could be a little better. The decks fill up quickly but that's a sign of growth. Maybe bring back the shuttles?

pros: Aside from the obvious benefit of working for a place with a mission as amazing as St. Jude, there are tangible value-adds of working here that make it very evident that St. Jude values their workforce. Our health benefits are *amazing* and SO affordable, we have great time off packages for sick and vacation, we get tuition reimbursement, 7% put into our 403B,  money added to our FSA for childcare, adoption assistance, an amazing on-site gym, a *farmer's market* all summer --  there's even an on-site car washing service.
cons: The scheduling flexibility and work-from-home options are still a bit old fashioned, but I think the goal is to keep folks as connected to the mission as possible, and that means being on campus.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Memphis, TN
pros: They care about their employees.
cons: Sometimes leadership jumps into things too quickly before taking careful consideration and asking people on the front lines what they need or what would be most effective.

review_title: Good experience while there but Very poor while seeking Employment from within or as external candidate
job_title: Research Lab Specialist in Cordova, TN
pros: Good Benefits, Average pay, Easy work environment good work life balance. One feels good work for a good cause.
cons: Weird Recruitment policies,  You do not hear from them for months and then they show up as interviewed but not selected however,  no one  even called you over phone for discussion. The recruitment process is painfully slow.

review_title: One of the most incredible facilities in the world.
pros: The best reason was the kids, then there was a clinical ladder for self-advancement, great benefits, new equipment, and the Docs listen to parents, nurses, etc. Best teamwork ever, whatever department I worked in. The patient was actually the primary focus of 90% of the staff, which made it a really cohesive atmosphere. Then there are the kids coming to visit after therapy, sharing graduations, weddings, introducing their spouses and children years later. You can really make a difference in someone's life here.
cons: Changes constantly, which may not actually be a con. Felt some of the new computer programs actually hindered instead of improved patient care. Took a lot of time away from actual patient care.

review_title: Employment with a sense of purpose
pros:
There are innumerable benefits to working with St. Jude. However, I will attempt to highlight some that I find to be most important, as I view Glassdoor as an opportunity to provide real insight to potential employees. Also, I want to clarify that my bias will be towards clinical care, as I am a registered nurse. I have no first hand knowledge of other areas.  So, as they say, caveat emptor.

First and foremost, there is our guiding mission.  "No child should die in the dawn of life." The work that we do on a daily basis does indeed help save lives.  I have seen advances in treatment and outcomes first hand.  It is slow and incremental, but it's there.

Our benefits are better than the norm. I've compared our benefits to other institutions over the last five years, and dollar for dollar, ours are better.  I'm sure that there are exceptions to that, based on personal needs and familial situations, but on average I'd pit our benefits package against almost any employer in Memphis. 

Work/life balance.  12 hour shifts can be brutal, but our ability to self-schedule helps ensure that we can have the time we need to recover.  There are instances where changes have to be made, and we don't always agree with them.  BUT, that's a risk you run with any employer.  We also have the added advantage of paid holidays, personal time, PTO and sick time to supplement our days away from the job.  Many of us take that for granted, but for most hospitals give employees less time away.  And they typically have ZERO paid holidays.

Non-clinical employment opportunities.  There comes a time in our lives (as nurses) where the bedside is no longer an option.  It could be age, physical condition, or mental fatigue.  Regardless, there are numerous options away from the clinical setting for those that would like a change.  Yes, there is competition. No, there aren't always positions when we want them.  But in life, patience is a virtue.

Lastly, I would say a sense of camaraderie. This is both a pro and a con. Many shifts (again, I am speaking solely to nursing) and units feel very much like family.  We can be very tight knit, supporting one another in times of distress, whether it's professional or personal.  We celebrate triumph, commiserate with one another during defeat, and we mourn our losses as one. I am proud to work on my unit, and I call many of my colleagues friends.  I've not felt the same in previous roles, so I embrace it.
cons:
It would be dishonest of me to omit the flaws that I see (personally), so I'll outline them as best i can. 

As I mentioned, there is a sense of camaraderie and of family.  With that, though, comes the formation of cliques and aloof behavior.  It waxes and wanes, but it does happen.  Often, we are able to "self-correct", but sometimes it leads to alienation of new employees.  It's something of which we must all be mindful.  And like most families, we have our share of dysfunctional family members who are negative, loud, or downright cantankerous. We are but human.

Salary. I'm sure I've never met anyone who was completely satisfied with their compensation package. That said, I sometimes feel as if we aren't as competitive as we could be.  We as an organization set ourselves apart from other hospitals in most regards, but then choose to use local market comparisons for pay.  It seems counterintuitive if the objective is to recruit premier talent from across the country.  Adjusting for cost of living, we are still paid less than nurses at similar institutions with similar prestige (UCSF, Dana Farber, CHOP, and Stanford to name a few). 

Paid Time Off. As I previously stated, I feel like we have sufficient time off.  The con is that we continue to place time off in multiple buckets (sick, family sick and vacation).  My preference would be to see my current time off placed into a single PTO bucket, for use at my discretion.  While I'm sure there are those who use sick time on a consistent basis, I know a number of individuals who are no longer accruing sick time because they have reached the maximum allowed.  My concern is that other entities that have made the transition from Sick/Vacation route to PTO have decreased the overall benefit, and that would be detrimental. 

Limited advancement potential. While there are a number of roles away from the clinical area for nurses, there is limited upward potential within inpatient nursing.  Each unit has 6 coordinators, and there are only four manager roles.  It can be discouraging if you desire any sort of upward progression.  Couple that with poor to non-existent career guidance, and you have created an environment that encourages one to look outside the hospital for advancement.  

Shift differentials. A common complaint is the loss of shift differential for time off. If a dayshift employee takes time away from work (vacation/sick/personal time), then they are paid their normal salary.  A night shift employee who takes time away is "penalized" for taking time away, as the 20% night shift differential is not paid on unworked hours.   I'm also aware that the shift differential is intended to compensate employees for the hardships placed on shift workers who must adapt to unusual working hours.  My personal feeling is that it's equally difficult to "flip-flop" from a night to day circadian rhythm and that the hardship of shift work doesn't end just because I've chosen to take a day off.  I would also point out that it is not unprecedented.  The federal government currently pays shift workers differential for unworked hours, as do many state governments.  Additionally, there are entire industries that do as well.  

All that being said, none of the cons I've listed are deal breakers for me.  I only include the cons to illustrate both sides to the same coin.

pros: One of the best places to work! This research hospital is serious about its mission to advance cures and means of prevention for pediatric catastrophic diseases. Whatever your role is here, you know you are contributing to this cause. The senior leadership is amazing. You have ample opportunities to voice ideas or concerns, and leadership listens. Benefits are great.  And at the end of the day you leave St. Jude knowing that you contributed to the advancement of a cure for pediatric cancer not only for St. Jude patients but children world-wide as St. Jude has a global impact.
cons: I have no cons. It's been a blessing and honor to work at St. Jude.

job_title: Clinical Research Monitor II in Memphis, TN
pros: Family First, Flexible, Awesome Management, Great work environment, Great team...
cons: There were no promotions within my group of 18+ during the 2 years I was employed, but this seems to be changing.  My team was only allowed to work from home 2 days per week for a job that is essentially a decentralized position - not a con per say but an inconvenience and limits hiring outside the Memphis area unless a person is willing to move to Memphis.

review_title: Hiding daily from bullying...dont apply if you can help it!
job_title: AR Billing and Collection Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: The patients are well taken care of and treated like royalty! Dr. Downing is the best! Thats the best and only Pro about this place...
cons: I have been here for quite some time. Ive made complaints about the mistreatment received and shown to not only staff but the management that has recently been hired has fallen right into the riff-raff. She's right in the middle of the gossip groups. Spreading lies and creating tremendous turmoil amongst us. The new system that was brought in has made it harder for us to do our jobs because NO ONE in this office is trained to use it properly. This is not only a hindrance for me to do my job- which I can do effortlessly- but it creates an issue for other people in the office to complain and gossip because they cannot work do to the fact they don't know HOW to work. You've hired incompetent people. From the entry level, to the top management in this office. I see so many "immediate termination" issues daily. Coworkers discussing patient info in front of patient family's, employees outside on personal cell phones all day, name calling with profane labels and racial slurs, security even allowed a car in with weed smoke and loud music onto the campus!! Amongst other things that management turns a blind eye to to keep it off their desk. HR knows most of this but won't do anything about it because its been documented before and hasn't changed. Im typing this review right now sitting next to 3 employees discusssing another employees FMLA status and why she needs to be fired and how they "wish she wasn't here." The employee they are talking about in an exemplary worker and works circles around us all...even when she misses days. She works sick, has lost her dad, her mother in law, her home amongst other issues and still manages to come and work tirelessly. But they are just bullying her with management looking right past it. Thats just one example of how much people take from others here and nothing is done. There are many other examples. The public doesn't know the darkside of this once beloved institution and rightfully so....however, if we can't get the help we need here, From the inside, outside help has to be sought and used. I love my job, and I give 200% daily all while working with a debilitating illness that keeps me struggling to stay encouraged, but I do so. But to deal with bullying, scrutiny, disrespect, name calling, incompetence, hearsay, laziness, and discrimination from this place daily is very tiring and cruel. Fix this...before it hurts this place!!!

pros: St. Jude offers numerous benefits and packages to employees, in addition to the fact that salaries are competitive compared to other places. I love the culture of St. Jude and the care offered to employees. I came to St. Jude for a short period of time and it's been 10 years since I started! St. Jude offers numerous opportunities to grow professionally. In addition, the cost of living in the Memphis area is low compared to other places, which allows me to offer a better quality of life to my family.
cons: Needs to be more inclusive and diverse, but St. Jude now is moving towards this direction.

review_title: Great place to work as a Biostatistician
pros: Leadership, Mission, Coworkers, Sense of purpose, facilities, excellent cafeteria, fitness center.   Defined career ladder with room to advance.  Continuing education opportunities.   Health Insurance benefits are good and start on day 1.
cons: Downtown Memphis traffic, big campus so it takes a while to learn your way around.  Orientation is very helpful.

pros: Coming from the Automotive Aftermarket business into the Medical field has been rewarding.  For me, I am learning and seeing new things everyday.  The benefits are unbelievable and everyone is genuine.  Some would think seeing sick children is sad but knowing you are part of a team that is working diligently to save their lives is so rewarding.  It doesn't matter what position you are in, whether you are an Administrative Specialist or a Doctor, you make a huge contribution to the institution.
cons: Being fairly new, I can only give you insight into a few things.  There seems to be too many sub-departments or it could be that I don't understand how hospitals operate.

pros: St. Jude runs like a well-oiled machine. A company I can be proud to work for, with a mission I really care about. Great people, great management always willing to help if you are unsure about something. Everyone is treated with respect, no matter what your position is. The benefits are great. They are always going the extra mile for their employees and their well being. Kay Kafe is awesome, you will never go hungry at St. Jude. There is definitely room for advancement, and a ton of learning opportunities! Work/life balance is normal, the same for any full-time position. Competitive wages. I absolutely love it here!
cons: The elevator in parking garage 3.

review_title: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital's mission and vision need to be preserved: No Child Should Die in the Dawn of Life
pros: Amazing talented people from all over the world come here to share and work with their colleagues to make a difference in their lives and lives of St. Jude's children.
cons:
Very unfortunate to write this cons, for this noble institution, when it started its mission half a century ago.

Administrators of the hospital management, from higher levels - CEO, CIO, CSO, PI level, and all of their wives, siblings, parents who hold management supervisory positions for good talented employees working under them at Stjude, DO NOT seem to care of this "people institution - run by using our public money (not government money or their family money), other than they getting their fat salaries for their own benefits such as their retirement planning. 

Families and friends hired by them, during almost 5 - 30+ years out of normal legal "hiring processes defined in labor department's laws for non-profit organizations" need to be reviewed along with HR department's current and past leaderships, if suspected, at least during the past five years, who have been continuing abusing employees and their benefits and preventing them to be part of Stjude's success story.  

Most of the employees in management (manager level up) looks like running their own cult environment, disconnected from their top levels with their blessings, enjoying fat pay checks, claiming or showing they're exempt status privileged group so benefits are higher for them, which DO NOT based on their merit, education level, and skills - with so MANY  subordinates under them.

Management staff need to be picked up from junior staff by referendum and merit basis by an  advisory committee. 

Old Stjude management buddy style must be abolished soon before it's too late.

pros: I've been an employee at St. Jude for over 15 years and truly believe that it is a Great Place to Work.  Our current management is really making great strides in retaining employees as seen in many of the additional benefits that have been added recently.  This makes for employees that are even more loyal than before as we feel like we are being recognized.  Our benefits are great and teamwork is evident.
cons: I cannot identify any cons of working at St. Jude.

pros: As a life-long Memphian, I have always known about St. Jude and the awesome work they do and was thrilled to be able to join the team here in January of this year. This is truly my dream job! From the cleaning staff to the cook and all the way to the CEO, Dr. Downing, the family feel of this place is overwhelming. St. Jude truly does care for its employees. I wake up thankful each and every day to be able to come work at this awesome place.
cons: Because St. Jude has grown so fast, parking is an issue right now. I'm confident that in the next few months, more parking will be added.

pros: St. Jude has an outstanding mission, great culture & benefits.  I've been here 10 years and I have no intention of leaving!   Wonderful leadership with an aggressive growth strategy.
cons: I understand there are always instances where this may not be for everyone, but I have not had any issues.  Don't let the naysayers deter you.  You have to make that determination on your own.

review_title: I've never felt so valued as an employee, as I do at St. Jude.
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Memphis, TN
pros:
The pros of working here cannot simply be summed up in one review, but I'll give it a shot.
-Our Mission
-Salary
-Communication from management and our CEO
-Excellent time off and retirement benefits
-Fantastic Insurance Plan
-The Best Co-workers, which really are like family
cons: As far as cons, I can't say anything about St. Jude itself. I wasn't too keen on moving to Memphis at first; I wouldn't have even put it on my top 20 cities to move to. However, once arriving in Memphis, I've found it a lot nicer and safer than statistics show. Not to mention, the cost of living is impeccable.

pros: The attitudes of people here are more positive and professional.  When I first interviewed here, everyone was smiling.  Even the people in the halls that weren't part of my interview.  I thought it must be an act.  There must be someone here who hates their job.  But I've come to see that people here truly are happy for a reason.  Its a very good place to work and there are too many reasons to list why.  Just know St. Jude has low turnover for a reason.
cons: Pressure to get the flu shot each year gets annoying for those who choose not to get one.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Memphis, TN
pros: St. Jude is an awesome place to work for .The higher ups treat the employees with respect and always show their appreciation.It is an honor to work for a company that does so much for sick children.
cons: The department I work in, is a different story.The Pharmacists do not show respect to the technicians for the very hard work they do.I also feel  there are several employees that don't know how to work as a team.And most of all, We never have enough staff to cover the workload.

pros: It is inspiring to work every day toward a mission of saving children and supporting science that will help create new treatments and cures. St. Jude has incredible resources to support scientific innovation and pursuing big ideas and there is a lot of communication and collaboration among lab-based scientists and clinical researchers. Also I personally love living in Memphis after moving here from California - it's got a lot going on for a mid-sized city and has beautiful outdoor spaces, botanic gardens, neighborhoods etc. and people are genuinely nice.
cons: Some departments are better to work in than others - this is probably true of every institution.

review_title: St Jude is a great place
job_title: Research Lab Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Great team work, talented workers, focused aims make St Jude Children's Research Hospital a great place to work.  St Jude is oriented towards providing world class care to little patients for free.  This is godly work done purely to save children.  I am proud to be a part of St Jude.
cons: I can't think of any.  It will be a blessing to maintain what St Jude is doing so the great work continues...

pros: I have worked at St. Jude for 2 years and still find that my excitement from day one is renewed each day.  While there are challenges, I am encouraged by our CEO and senior leaders who are constantly asking "how can we get better"? As a part of the team that gets to work on some of these challenges, I am living my dream job.
cons: St. Jude has a long reputation as being a great place to work and it is... however, the challenges of growth are complicated by employees who are resistant to change. The desire to be the best sometimes put people ill prepared to lead in leadership positions.

review_title: Third Time Working at St. Jude - This Time I am Staying!!!
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Memphis, TN
pros: The culture at St. Jude is one of inclusiveness. You feel like you are a part of something greater than yourself, because you are. The miracles that originate here reach across the planet. The benefits are wonderful and there is always something special going on.
cons: It took me three times over a ten year span, starting as a temp employee, to finally grasp a permanent position. There is a lot of competition to work here.  Because the campus is growing it can be difficult to find a parking place if you are not an early bird.

pros:
People always ask me how I work here, isn't it a sad place? My reply is always the same. We meet patients and families that are going through the worst time of their lives. It is both humbling and rewarding to be the support these precious patients and families need. Not only do we provide excellent care, we touch lives every day. I am proud and honored to say that I work for St. Jude!
I have never felt so valued and appreciated by another employer. Our CEO is amazing!
cons: Although this is a very rewarding job, it can be challenging. Most days are happy and fun, but we occasionally have sad days.

review_title: I couldn't imagine working anywhere else
job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: There is no greater mission that the mission of St. Jude. The people here are amazing and amazingly talented. Not only are we making scientific breakthroughs every day and curing childhood catastrophic diseases, but we put people first; patients, families, employees, everyone! We are all equal and important here.
cons: The only cons are things St. Jude is working on; limited parking - they created the "Parking is Fun" Campaign, Crowded cafeteria - they increased outdoor seating, food truck availability, and brought in grubhub so you can prepay and quickly grab your food, all while they plan out better long term solutions.

pros: This is a very positive place to work. There is constant learning, research, and professional development going on for all employees. Plus, there are fun things too, like employee appreciation events, farmer's market, and talent talks. The focus is our patients and that is very motivating. If you come here, you'll want to stay!
cons: Traffic getting here sometimes is not fun, but security has made it easy and quicker to get in and out for your shift daily. Also, sometimes rules are bent for certain hiring managers or PhDs.

review_title: Research and development to help children achieve adulthood
pros:
Transparency - ease of work between cross-functional teams
Resources available - if St. Jude doesn't have something needed to meet a goal - they will partner with someone to get that resource - the mission is the children
