Great colleagues with extensive range of experiences, cultures, and talents
Fun place to work - with a can-do attitude not seen often in industry
Focus on finding the solution
cons: Systems are changing (as all of medical research is moving into new systems) - for the good - but the transition is never easy

pros: Everyone buys into the mission of finding cures & saving children. It is a very diverse community both the patients and the employees.  I work with physicians and scientists that are truly "top of their field". People are happy to share their knowledge.
cons: The only con I can think of is the  realization that not all of our patients have a good outcome.

job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Memphis, TN
pros: Besides feeling like you're part of a bigger cause, St. Jude really makes its employees feel appreciated and supported. Compared to other opportunities, a research position at St. Jude is more secure and provides better benefits and slightly higher compensation. It's also an extremely collaborative, non-competitive environment.
cons: At times, there is a lot of red tape and things can be slow-moving (ordering supplies, new equipment, office space, etc).  There also is a lack of space and a ton of shared space, which is not always ideal in science. However, a new research is currently being built so hopefully this will solve some of these problems.

review_title: Amazing commitment to St Jude mission and employees
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Memphis, TN
pros: St. Jude is totally dedicated to the health and safety of their patients. The resources available to patients and families are incredible. The St. Jude community is welcoming and everyone works together to achieve the goal of making childhood catastrophic diseases a thing of the past. There are great opportunities for networking, career growth, and professional development. It is a very supportive environment and there is an incredible diversity of people with a respect for the strengths and perspectives of others.
cons: As a postdoctoral research fellow there are relatively limited opportunities to work with and mentor undergraduates (versus on a university campus).

review_title: St. Jude finds cures and saves lives, and is the best place on earth to serve!
pros: St. Jude is more than a job. We all need to pay bills and live. At St. Jude, every day you are part of an organization that is the leader in finding cures to many catastrophic illnesses that impact children and adults. There is no amount of money that can match the personal reward you feel. And they have the best benefits package of any company.
cons: Some of their older buildings will need new paint and carpet in a few years.

job_title: Manager, Digital Business in Memphis, TN
pros: The people are wonderful to work with. Everyone has a common mission and vision and is willing to go the extra mile to complete projects and make everything as great as it can be. There are so many opportunities to find your path and make the most of your job, to advance your area/department, and to advance the institution. We have the top minds in the world, and it's great to be a part of one of the best children's pediatric cancer hospitals in the nation.
cons: St. Jude is a very large place, so there's a large work demand and a hierarchy for approvals.

pros:
Our compelling mission.  The mission of St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital is to advance cures, and means for prevention, for pediatric catastrophic diseases through research and treatment. Consistent with the vision of our founder, Danny Thomas, no child is denied treatment based on race, religion or a family’s ability to pay.
We have the best benefits.
We have a living wage of $15. an hour minimum
cons: St. Jude is growing so fast.  We are running out of space. No worries, new buildings are going up every day.

review_title: Excellent place to work, but there are always bad apples.
pros: St Jude is very proud of its employees and frequently has employee appreciation events. They have a great mission, wonderful state-of-the-art facilities, and are constantly improving those facilities. Not to mention, you are helping to cure kids!
cons: I worked on the research end of the company, and although there is a lot of really good science going on, there is some bad science as well. I got involved with a bad fit as my first "real job" out of college. It literally drained my love of science out of me.

pros: The St. Jude CEO, Dr. Downing is: supportive, open, encouraging; thinks of patients & staff always; the staff in turn truly like and support Dr. Downing for all he does. Recently several staff got together and presented him with a thank you banner. People talk in the halls about how much they appreciate him. That’s a true testament to this leader.
cons: There are not really cons to working for St. Jude, the hospital. Advice: there should be an adult hospital like it!

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Memphis, TN
pros: St. Jude has cutting edge research equipment and researchers, and everyone and everything is freely available to you. You can take your project to the furthest reach of your imagination, which is an extraordinary feeling. St. Jude also has ways of relocating you to a better working environment.
cons: Not all labs and managers are the same. If you are in a lab where your boss is treating you very badly, you often feel stuck. While St. Jude has ways of helping you to relocate to a new lab, it can feel like you have no support.

pros: Our Mission is why you choose to work at St. Jude. Knowing that the work you do, whatever it might be, contributes to the mission of advancing cures and means of prevention for pediatric catastrophic diseases, is enough. But there is more - the level of transparency from senior leadership is like none other, the ability to submit ideas for improvement both big and small is encouraged and rewarded, the people are amazing and the patient-families that we serve deserve the best.
cons: There may be seasons of change which can be hard, but nothing that you wouldn't experience at any large organization.

pros: Highlights include a collaborative environment, a feeling of community encouraged by the adminstration, ample equipment and materials to complete a project successfully, emphasis on creative solutions, and support for new ideas
cons: Parking can be tight sometimes, but we do have free parking on campus and new parking structures coming. As with all jobs, sometimes there is so much to do you wonder how you will get it done, but work-life balance is encouraged. The biggest issue is the driving sense of mission you will develop vs only 24 hours in a day!

review_title: Challenging, but rewarding Pediatric Oncology and hematology setting
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Memphis, TN
pros: Wonderful patients, families and care teams.  Cutting edge research and  clinical are with latest technologies...so much to learn every day.  Education of RNs and doctors is focused and top notch!  Every employee here makes a difference in the lives of these patients and families, and is valued.  We celebrate life every day!
cons: It's very important to remember to take care of yourself with healthy work and personal life balance.  Healthy resilience is a targeted goal here so take advantage of the resources.

pros: ALSAC is the fundraising arm of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Just knowing that I play a part in raising funds for the catastrophically sick children is reward enough, but the pay is good, the benefits are excellent, and I couldn't be happier with my boss and my job.
cons: Management is working on being more transparent but they have a little way to go. It would also be nice to know about events on campus in advance.

review_title: Research oriented and great learning experience
job_title: Senior Data Warehouse Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros:
St. Jude invests heavily on training and self improvement
St. Jude encourages use of open source technology and latest developments in the IT field
St. Jude is best place to work if are starting your career as most of the work is research oriented and provides opportunities to learn
cons: Sometimes, management in few academic departments can be dogmatic and political. You have to little lucky to avoid such departments. Human resources department is very fair and balances out these disparities in style of working among departments as much as possible.

pros: at the end of my life I will have made a difference that I can be proud of.  Benefits are the best I have ever seen.  CEO is a true servant leader.
cons: for someone coming from a publicly traded company (or anything other than a non-profit), making the transition to a non-profit culture can be more of a challenge than what you would expect.

review_title: Review of the research side of St Jude
job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Memphis, TN
pros:
For the research side of St Jude your work environment is typically governed by your principal investigator, however there many common benefits we all receive:

Competitive salary
Strong organizational culture
Great insurance benefits (to cover the employee's medical alone, your contribution is $0)
Strong focus on employee wellness, including gym and counseling plan
Strong focus on career development including paid tuition and seminars to promote growth.
cons: Many people are nervous to move to Memphis, however the city has made great strides in developing a fun and active culture, and this is not a native Memphian writing this.

pros: Working in an administrative capacity at St. Jude, I absolutely loved my department, coworkers, and the job itself. A wonderful place to work. I loved going in every day.
cons:
None to speak of, regarding my department. Loved my time there, and would go back in a heartbeat. 
I think they may have to expand/enlarge the Kay Kafe at some point, given the expansion of the place. Longer hours might be beneficial for those who eat late as well, as the deli and most of the vendors close down by 2pm.

review_title: Desirable workplace if you are in the right job
pros: St. Jude is highly respected, both in the city of Memphis but throughout the United States as a whole. It feels good to work for an employer that is held in such high regard. The benefits are St. Jude are really pretty good – the 403b retirement plan (with 7% contribution by St. Jude!) and the medical, dental and vision benefits are also really nice too. The people here are generally nice and most of them are happy to be here. St. Jude is growing and is financially healthy, which bodes well for future employment and growth opportunities.
cons:
Unfortunately, like most employers, St. Jude has it’s flaws. In my particular position in Enterprise Informatics, I am the primary (well, really the only) resource in my area. If an issue arises, I pretty much have to respond to resolve the problem. Essentially, that makes me a resource that is on-call 24 hours a day, 7 days per week, 365 days per year. Of course, it really isn’t reasonable for someone to be on-call 24/7/365 but that is basically what it feels like and management has pretty much admitted that is the reality of my particular position. It was pretty disappointing to learn that being on-call all the time was the reality and the expectation of management, as that wasn’t mentioned in the job description when I applied and it wasn’t mentioned to me as a requirement of the job when I was interviewing for the position. This is a pretty big job requirement to somehow get left out of the job description and not get mentioned when interviewing candidates. How does it manage to get left out? A candidate should not find this out after accepting the job and beginning to work at St. Jude.

The biggest negative about being the only resource in my area (and being on-call 24/7/365 as a result) is that it makes it difficult to mentally separate myself from work, even after leaving St. Jude for the day. It leaves me wondering what I would do if I am out to eat with friends or family or at a movie theater and suddenly receive a call for help – will I be able to respond in a reasonable amount of time? What is actually a reasonable amount of time in my situation? Should I even go out to eat or to see a movie under these circumstances? Do I need to clear my plans with my boss before going? I certainly don’t want there to be an expectation that I have to clear my personal life & weekend plans with my boss, as that encroaches too much on an individual’s personal life to be reasonable. I haven’t been told that this is the case, of course, because no one in management has ever made it clear what the expectations are for responding to a call situation.

 I also have to think about it whenever I am considering traveling on weekends outside of my normal work hours. What happens if I receive a call while I am away? Will I be able to find a business, hotel, etc that has Wi-Fi? What if I am on the interstate or highway miles from any place with usable Wi-Fi? Again, do I need to clear my plans with my boss before going? What happens if I cannot respond for whatever reason (bad cell service, lack of WiFi access, etc.)? Will I be reprimanded? Will I be written up? Will I be fired? The expectations of management and of St. Jude as an organization have never really been clear in this regard. There are lots of little details like this that I am forced to think about because of the constant on-call aspect of my job, when I really should be free to focus on enjoying my life outside of work. Since there isn’t a clear separation between the two (work and personal life), it is sometimes difficult to enjoy my life outside of St. Jude.

While it would be true to say that I don’t receive a call every night or even every week but it is still a difficult position because no one can truly be available to respond to an issue all of the time. Life happens and sometimes people aren’t available. What happens when I cannot respond? I imagine that if I told my manager that I couldn’t respond, then he would try to deal with it himself (I have no true backup, so technically my manager would almost certainly be my backup). The problem with that idea is that he doesn’t truly know some of my work well enough to fix a lot of issues by himself. He would probably need my help resolving a decent percentage of system issues, which would mean me trying to walk him through resolving the problem over the phone. Of course, in that situation I might as well have taken the call and resolved the issue myself in the first place. So, relying on a backup person (ie, my manager) to provide me with some down time probably wouldn’t work out very well.

It is an unfortunate situation and I wish that there was a better solution that allowed me to truly be off duty on certain nights or weekends. I know an obvious suggestion that people might mention would be communicating with my supervisor on this particular issue but I am a little worried that this might cause some friction between myself and my manager if he senses that I am unhappy with this particular expectation of the job. I feel that it would be easier and clearer for everyone if there was a specific policy that covered this situation (ie the “always on-call staff”), as it shouldn’t be up to me to have to clear up confusion over a pretty important job requirement like this one.

To sum it up: St. Jude as a workplace as a whole would get 4 stars but I can only give 3 stars in my case because I feel that the 24/7/365 on-call expectation isn’t a realistic option, encroaches too much on personal life and should have been communicated clearly to me as a requirement of the position beforehand. 

 If I had truly known about the 24/7/365 on-call expectation beforehand, I would have requested significantly more money (either in the form of a large bump to my yearly salary or as on-call pay, something I currently do not receive) before ever accepting the job. I certainly wouldn’t do it for my present salary and wouldn’t do it for anything less than a six figure salary.

 I know HR does salary surveys for our positions but I highly doubt they are taking into account that some of our IT positions essentially require us to be on-call 24/7/365 whenever they are comparing our positions and salaries to the positions and salaries of other employers. As a result, the salary surveys in some of our cases are almost certainly an apples-to-oranges comparison.

If I leave St. Jude in the future it will almost certainly be because of the 24/7/365 on-call expectation and St. Jude’s lack of clarification on how we can respond to call requests and have work/life balance as well. Long-term, I have a feeling that is probably what I will do, so that I can set appropriate boundaries between work and personal life and so that I don’t have to be married to a cell phone and laptop every night and weekend.

pros: As a nurse here, you are appreciated for the work you do by the administration. The workload is fair. Your patients are able to receive the best care because of the resources we have to provide them with practically anything they ask for.
cons: You are restricted on what all you can do for your patient. Although our nursing license allows certain procedures, St. Jude restricts what the RN does and requires an NP for simple things. Our critical thinking as an RN is not trusted.

review_title: Good place to work but still has drawbacks
job_title: Administrative Support Specialist in Memphis, TN
pros: Good health coverage, beautiful campus, college tuition program is great and increased every so often.  I was hired in making 8K less than I had previously but was brought back up to my same salary within 3 1/2 years.
cons: I was informed when interviewed that they needed an person for a faculty member that went through this position very frequently and that they wanted someone who was able to tolerate being yelled out, manage frequent temper tantrums, bad attitude, difficult to work for, went through assistants frequently, etc.   I found out within the first week that this does go on quite frequently in the office.  What I found most interesting about the situation is that it is tolerated at all - 50 years ago, maybe, but now it is quite strange.  And it is such common knowledge that the departmental director, admin director, and directors/faculty of other departments are aware of this behavior, frequently discussed, joked about even, but is still found to be acceptable .  I am not aware of any other faculty members behaving this way, but I still think it's is ultimately unacceptable behavior for a grown, educated adult.  And also ultimately unacceptable for such a large and world known corporation to allow this behavior as "acceptable" for so long and continue to do so.  Ultimately, I like working for St. Jude and currently have no plans to leave - but a little less daily stress would be nice.

pros: I was very impressed with the time frame that it took for my entire hiring process.  I was contacted promptly for an initial phone screening and was given clear details and expected time frames on next steps with my interview and hiring process.  My whole experience was easy going and professional and only showed what I could expect with joining this organization.
cons: I honestly do not have or foresee any cons!

review_title: I love working at St. Jude.
job_title: Medical Technologist IV in Memphis, TN
pros: There are so many great reasons to work at St. Jude: the mission, the kids, the people. We're all working towards the same goal.
cons: There's a problem with nepotism in the department of Pathology. Some of the people in administration will hire friends over people with years of experience. I've even seen two new positions created so that friends could be hired.

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Memphis, TN
pros: Working with a great team of CRAs, the work culture here is amazing. I love how St. Jude recognizes the importance of work life balance and constantly find ways to relieve stress at work with little perks here and there. Very supportive immigration team! They are awesome. I particularly love how the immigration team came to welcome us during orientation/1st day at work. I have an amazing boss, I love how we work together to find cures and advance the treatment of childhood cancer! I love St. Jude!

review_title: The "BEST" place to work in Memphis, TN
pros: I am humbled and honored to work at St Jude it has been a rewarding career.  To work with a great TEAM has truly been a great place to work.  I consider our department to be FAMILY.  The mission statement of the hospital " to advance cures, and means of prevention, for pediatric catastrophic diseases through research and treatment. Consistent with the vision of our founder Danny Thomas, no child is denied treatment based on race, religion or a family's ability to pay."
cons: Some departments offer a variety of work schedules.

review_title: Horrible organization, full of backstabbers and liars
pros: None - There are no "Pros" for working at St. Jude. it is a company full of liars, backstabbers, hypocrites, and far worse.
cons: Watch your back and trust absolutely no one there! Do not consider anybody to be your friend. Go to work, work, go home and don't give the place a second thought, because they WILL throw you under the bus the first chance they get.

pros: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is a great place to work.  The mission is solid and the management is committed to staying current and providing opportunities for growth and advancement in all career paths, while staying true to the cause of finding cures and saving lives.  There is a connection/camaraderie between the staff  that helps to promote a caring and thoughtful environment.  The benefits are also great. If you are fortunate enough to work at St. Jude your life will be truly enriched.
cons: There are no cons working at St. Jude.

review_title: Great medicine and basic science but very mediocre clinical trials support infrastructure
job_title: Clinical Trials Administration in Memphis, TN
pros: Stellar reputation in pediatric oncology.  Great benefits.  Some very talented people on this campus.

pros: Far too many to list!

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Memphis, TN
pros: Great scientists to work with/for. One of the most collegial and collabaorative places I have worked. Their treatment of postdocs is top 5 if not number 1 in the country.
cons: I honestly can't think of anything negative to say. This is the best job I have had and I don't plan to leave any time soon. It is absolutely superb to be a postdoc here at St. Jude.

job_title: Senior Bioinformatics Scientist in Memphis, TN
pros: It's ranked as the No. 2 pediatric cancer hospital on U.S. News & World Report in 2019.   Well paid and have great chances to advance your career.  More importantly,  it's not only a job. We has strong missions to find cures and save children and we can make a big difference in the life of a child battling cancer.
cons: Nothing to complaint except the shortage of parking if you come to work after 9 AM.

pros:
Benefits- health insurance-individuals $36 monthly, 403b- 7% paid by employer, life insurance 43,000, tuition reimbursement $4000
The environment is pleasant.

job_title: Senior Clinical Analyst in Memphis, TN

cons: Seeing the children makes me want to work harder for them but it is sad at the same time.

pros: St. Jude is an amazing place to work.  The employees are very friendly and everyone is like a family.  Management is always available for any questions or concerns you may have.  I am so happy and honored to be a part of the St. Jude family.

pros: I love the mission of St. Jude. We have a great CEO who is not only compassionate about the patients, but the employees as well. Love working with my team.

job_title: Patient Care Associate in Memphis, TN
pros: Caring staff that really cares about the children and their families

review_title: You will never loss your motivation in St. Jude
pros: No matter what type of job you are working in St. Jude, doctor, nurse, researcher, security, cooker, gardener, driver, cleaner, etc., children and their families are always motivated you. People are happy in St. Jude., because we know what we are doing are helping children. Welcome to visit St. Jude. and feel our culture by yourself.
cons: The most down part is the location... But nothing can be perfect on the world.  Like when you fall in love with someone, you love his/her shortcoming not virtue.

review_title: What a wonderful enviroment, purposful, and full of amazing people!
pros: The people are wonderful who work here. The mission is second to none. The benefits make you feel respected and cared for.

pros: supportive collegial work place, good benefit, lots of perks,  do not forget that memphis is a great place to live and enjoy music

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Memphis, TN

The cafeteria food here is THE BEST and it's not expensive! The campus is beautiful. I absolutely adore working here.

job_title: Senior Research Technologist in Memphis, TN
pros: St. Jude  is a special place to work at! The energy that goes into the St. Jude mission is truly remarkable. The patients care and scientific research to further advance cures is the priority. I work in a leukemia research lab within the pharmaceutical sciences department. The research that is being done just within this department is inspiring.  It is also great to work for an organization that values their employees with competitive compensation and benefits.

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Memphis, TN

pros:

pros: St. Jude is amazing. There are so many things going on here that's making it not only a great place for patients and families to receive the best care possible, it's continuously striving to remain one of the greatest places to work!
cons: Not sure if there is one, but if there was, would say that keeping up with great initiatives.

pros: I have an amazing team. They are so intelligent and surprising nice. Everybody is all about the children. From the janitors and cooks to the doctors and upper management, we all know what we do is helping the kids. It’s an amazing feeling to eat with the kids daily. Best job I e ever had and I would recommend st Jude to anybody.
cons: Takes forever to start working. It took about 3 months to start working. Parking isn’t great so get here early.

pros: Great environment and fantastic core facilities with cutting edge technologies; unique place to improve both personal skills and team work abilities. Salaries are in the average or higher than national average.
cons: Not major concerns. Excellent place where it is easy to go a step ahead with their own career. Friendly and professional environment.

pros: I love the benefits as well as my coworkers. They really make St. Ju(d)e a place where I am happy to come to work every day.

Our patients are treated with kindness and dignity and spoiled whenever possible. There is such pride in witnessing this so frequently. Keeps one humble and thankful on a daily basis.

pros: This is the best place I ever worked in life.  I have been extremely pleased with my time here and can't wait to spend many more years contributing to the mission.

I found it very difficult to be promoted but other races with less education and experience were constantly promoted.  I came in with a Bachelor of Science from the University of Tennessee and was offered a position making $10/hr....what a shame

review_title: Excellent place for a Postdoctoral Fellow

In addition, the stipend and benefits are amazing for this career level. One especially unique and amazing thing is that many postdocs find a variety of opportunities for transitioning to a permanent position at St. Jude.

pros: Working to save the lives of countless children across the globe gives everyone a sense of pride in what they do at St. Jude.  The pay is what is expected from a non-profit organization but the benefits are second to none.  Amazing to see a global mission centered in one place.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Memphis, TN
pros: St Jude is a wonderful place to work. There are tons of benefits and it's a fairly laid back atmosphere. Additionally, there are tons of funds and resources, so monetary concerns are nearly nonexistant.

Throw in an incredible company culture and it’s no wonder no one ever leaves.
